statistics.description: The number of points scored.

statistics.description: Field Goal makes and attempts.

statistics.description: Free Throw makes and attempts.

statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.name: minutes
statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.name: assistTurnoverRatio
statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.name: rebounds
statistics.description: The total number of rebounds (offensive and defensive).

statistics.name: defensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the defense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot by the offense.

statistics.name: offensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the offense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot.

article.headline: BYU 97, Lamar 74
article.story: SALT LAKE CITY (AP) -- Brigham Young got off to a fast start against Lamar and Cougars coach Dave Rose said that led to team confidence. The Cougars (3-1) built a 16-6 lead on three 3-pointers by Brock Reichner, Jimmy Balderson and Lee Cummard and went on to 97-74 victory over Lamar Wednesday night at the Delta Center. The game was rescheduled to Salt Lake City, because Hurricane Rita forced the Texas school to alter its home schedule. BYU's Marriott Center was unavailable due to a Christmas show. "We had guys make big plays and big shots early. We got a lead and we kept it throughout," Rose said. "We're getting into our offense quickly, getting open shots and hitting shots and getting points early. It leads to confidence for our team." Balderson's 21 points led BYU. The Cardinals (1-4) stayed close through the first eight minutes, but BYU went on runs of seven and 10 points to capture a 36-19 lead with six minutes remaining. The Cougars managed their largest lead of the half at 44-23 when Keena Young hit a jumper with just over three minutes remaining. After trailing 48-35 at halftime, Lamar gave up a basket to Fernando Malaman to start the second half and then turned up the defensive pressure. Alan Daniels scored five straight points followed by a basket by Thomas Fairley to pull the Cardinals within eight at 50-42. BYU's Trent Plaisted answered with two baskets and a free throw to start a 12-0 Cougar run that ended with BYU holding a 62-42 lead. The Cardinals never challenged after that. Lamar coach Billy Tubbs was ejected after a Daniels' dunk closed the lead to 65-49 with 12:48 remaining. "BYU played great," said Lamar assistant coach Kermit Holmes. "They can really shoot. I've been watching a lot of basketball and I haven't seen many teams shoot like that." The Cougars' largest lead was 27 points at 88-61 and 90-63. Daniels led all scorers with 23 points. Barrow had 18 and Fairley 14. Daniels also had a game-high nine rebounds. BYU had an outstanding shooting night with 66 percent in the first half and 57 percent for the game. The Cougars also shot 50 percent from beyond 3-point range and 90 percent from the free throw line. Lamar shot 41 percent. Joining Balderson in double figures for the Cougars was Plaisted and Young with 16 and 10 points respectively. Young also led BYU with eight rebounds. BYU's Rashaun Broadus had a game high nine assists.
